reviews.review_title: The holy grail of holy grails. Buy this.
reviews.review_buyer_description: Brown eyes, Fair skin tone, Combination skin
reviews.review_text: I cannot stress this enough- this is hands down THE BEST moisturizer I have ever used, I wish I could bold and highlight and gold star this. I‚Äôve used this for like 3 years at this point, and I loved it so much but it‚Äôs expensive so I went on the hunt for dupes. The closest dupe is Inkey list, and it does not even hold a candle to this magnificent substance. I used to have oily skin and it was the only product that did not make me look shiny. Then I had cancer, went through chemo and this was THE ONLY PRODUCT of my skincare routine that I could still use (due to my changing skin needs and sensitivity at the time). Now, after cancer, my skin is dry and it‚Äôs the only product, again, that is perfect for my dry skin, but doesn‚Äôt make me feel or look like a grease, and gives me all the hydration I need. It is unscented, light weight, and must have some sort of magic in it. I buy a big tub maybe once or twice a year, because you need maybe a quarter pump to fully coat your face. I did the math, and it was more expensive for me to putz around with other moisturizers than to just splurge 2x a year on this and my skin thanks me greatly. If you have ‚Äúproblem‚Äù skin of honestly any kind, this is the best thing to use. I would like a commission from DE for how often and frequently I get people hooked on this. Thank you for listening to my Ted talk, and you‚Äôre welcome.

reviews.review_title: Not as it used to be
reviews.review_buyer_description: Brown eyes, Light skin tone, Combination skin
reviews.review_text: I've been using this cream for years and years and loved it so much, I'd always repurchase. Even with the price hikes as well as introduction of the refill packaging,  I continued to use it because this was my staple daily moisturizer. Never had too much trouble with refills/ packaging, but what I did have trouble with recently is the last time I repurchased the refill, my skin started turning red and burning. It never happened before so I thought maybe it's something else in my beauty routine. After a while I decided to test my theory and stopped using it all together. Used another moisturizer for a month. Then came back to this one. Sure enough, as soon as I started using it again, my skin started burning again. And not a mild burning sensation that goes away, but actual skin irritation. To me this is crazy that Drunk Elephant never mentioned any reformulations to the formula, but it is clear that the ingredients changed. So many other people are mentioning the same thing, seems to me this is not a coincidence. Also as a side note - the overall silence/ lack of education about their products for all of the tweens and younger people that keep buying those products and leaving reviews about damaged skin, is alarming to say the least. Be better! It's not that hard to be transparent and release a video on social media to make sure kids don't go and buy this stuff!

reviews.review_text: I never been a huge fan of trendy or overhyped product so I was very hesitant to buy, but I eventually purchased it because of the ingredients and clean composition. Yes, it is expensive, but compared to other expensive skin care products, there's a good amount of peptides and amino acids for the price you pay. It is definitely not a cream that will transform your skin overnight, but the growth factors in it would provide anti-aging and support to the skin on the long run. For reference, I'm 27 with acne-pro skin that also tends to be dehydrated as I use actives in my skincare. No clogged pores or pimples with this product, however it wasn't rich enough and irritated my skin. Keep in mind that this moisturizer has a PH of 4, which is quite low and acidic. On some days when my skin was already sensitive due to actives, this moisturizer literally burnt me. So unfortunately it is not a product for me, but it may work for someone else. If that works for you, I would say that it is a good product.

reviews.review_title: underwhelming, overpriced, not for dry skin
reviews.review_buyer_description: Fair skin tone, Dry skin
reviews.review_text: Not worth the price if you have dry, sensitive skin. Won't cause a reaction, but won't do anything extra or amazing. After hearing rave reviews, I was completely underwhelmed and returned after about 3 weeks.   I have very dry, sensitive skin. I have been using Elf's Superhydrate moisturizer for the last few years and I love that stuff; I started to use it when my skin was freaking out with perioral dermatitis, acne, etc. and it helped everything level out and has maintained my skin ever since. However, it is very basic and I am at the point I want to find something more than just maintenance. My goals:  - deeply moisturize and make my skin glow - DON'T TRIGGER MY PERIORAL DERMATITIS - don't cause a break out (I also have acne prone skin) - hydrate my fine lines and acne scars to make them less visible - help with anti-aging  while this product didn't trigger my perioral dermatitis (a big plus; it's extremely reactive so that's no small feat) or cause a break out, it left my skin feeling tight and unmoisturized. I thought at first I hadn't put enough on, so I tried layering two, three times, but that didn't change anything. It also felt what can best be described as gritty on my face, and I found it actually settled into my fine lines/scars and made them more noticeable.   After about two weeks I messed around and decided to treat it kind of like a serum. I put on one layer and then layered my usual Superhydrate moisturizer on top, and I found in that scenario my skin feel more moisturized than just the Superhydrate on it's own. However it certainly didn't do enough to justify the price point, especially if I would just have to layer my usual moisturizer on top anyways just to notice a slight difference. I also found it still settled into my fine lines. After a few days of that, I decided to give up and make the return. I'm currently trying the Lala Retro‚Ñ¢ Nourishing Whipped instead, and although it's only been a few days, I have been seeing more success with that.

reviews.review_title: Drugstore quality skincare for luxury prices.
reviews.review_buyer_description: Hazel eyes, Dry skin
reviews.review_text: I got a free sample from Ulta for my birthday month. I'd vaguely seen Drunk Elephant products in passing on the internet but they're clearly aimed at people who are younger but financially illiterate and don't demand anything from their skincare but eco friendly packaging and a laughably high price point for uncomfortable, sticky moisturizer that doesn't do much but sit on the skin. Because tiktok told them to buy it. I was shocked to learn It's sold for $22. The deluxe sample size, for a whopping 15ml. As I found that out, I was using it on my legs because it's simply not high quality enough to go on my face, and the alternative was the trash.  Really overpriced, absolutely mediocre face cream. When you apply it, it just feels like a drugstore night cream. Not particularly light or heavy. It doesn't melt into skin particularly well. It gave me a few CCs after one use, as many others reported, but that's not the reason I gave it one star. If it hadn't produced any negative effects like acne, it would still earn 1 star. It doesn't feel particularly nice when applied nor does it melt into skin particularly well or without residue, which is ridiculous for the luxury price point. For slightly more, you can purchase the Tatcha dewy skin cream, Pai's Anthemis (that's even less expensive IIRC), or similar, which are luxurious to apply and produce truly great results in the morning, better than a drugstore moisturizer. This is the price or idiotic 20 year old kids buying everything they see an influencer hawk on tiktok. Slap a label with a hippy-dippy name like drunk elephant, put drugstore brands in plastic, pastel, muted packaging that looks like it came out of a dystopian drama, and charge $68 for 1.6 ounces, and credit-illiterate Gen-Zers will buy it.
